StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: NHLBI TOPMed: Pulmonary Hypertension and the Hypoxic Response in Sickle Cell Disease

Person.Organization: UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT CHICAGOUNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: The TOPMed acknowledgement statement can be found at: https://topmed.nhlbi.nih.gov/acknowledgements. Please also include "This project was supported in part by grant nos. R25 HL003679 and R01 HL079912 from NHLBI, by Howard University GCRC grant no 2MOI RR10284-10 from NCRR, NIH, Bethesda, MD, and by the intramural research program of the National Institutes of Health (USA)."
Policy.ic_specific_access_term: There is one consent group in NHLBI TOPMed: Pulmonary Hypertension and the Hypoxic Response in Sickle Cell Disease. The consent group is Disease-specific: Use of the data must be related to Sickle Cell Disease. Requestor must provide documentation of local IRB approval. Requestor agrees to make results of studies using the data available to the larger scientific community. Requestor must provide a letter of collaboration with the primary study investigator(s).

ConsentGroup.title: Disease-Specific (Sickle Cell Disease, IRB, PUB, COL)
ConsentGroup.name: DS-SCD-IRB-PUB-COL
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: Use of the data must be related to Sickle Cell Disease. Requestor must provide documentation of local IRB approval. Requestor agrees to make results of studies using the data available to the larger scientific community. Requestor must provide a letter of collaboration with the primary study investigator(s).

ConsentGroup.title: Exchange Area (IRB, PUB, COL)
ConsentGroup.name: EA-IRB-PUB-COL
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: Use by NHLBI WGS study investigators only. There is one consent group for this study: DS-SCD-IRB-PUB-COL. Use of the data must be related to Sickle Cell Disease. Requestor must provide documentation of local IRB approval. Requestor agrees to make results of studies using the data available to the larger scientific community. Requestor must provide a letter of collaboration with the primary study investigator(s).
